did.abstract: Ben East was a prominent Michigan outdoorsman and outdoor writer. The bulk of his career was spent as a writer and editor for Outdoor Life, a nationally distributed outdoors magazine. Additionally, he wrote for a number of Michigan-based newspapers and publications, and was a prominent Michigan conservationist.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: Materials were donated to the library by David and Kay Richey (donor no. 9852) in January 30, 2007.

accruals.p: Periodic additions to the records are not expected.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is not held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Ben East papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Ben East (1898-1990) grew up hunting and fishing on his family's farm outside of Holly, Michigan, but didn't began his career as an outdoor writer until his mid-20s when he began selling short stories to magazines and local newspapers such as the Detroit News. The quality of his freelance work led to a permanent, full-time position establishing and editing the outdoor page of the Grand Rapids Press in 1926. He spent the next twenty years working for the newspaper and became a well-known and well-respected writer and lecturer. In 1946 he was honored with the invitation to present a talk to the National Geographic Society.

East continued to write freelance magazine stories during his tenure at the Grand Rapids Press, and in 1946 he was invited to joint the editorial staff of Outdoor Life, a nationally distributed outdoors magazine. He worked as a writer, field editor, and senior field editor during the almost thirty years he was employed by the magazine. The bulk of East's editorial work involved creating monthly regional inserts to be included in Outdoor Life subscriptions sent to the Great Lakes states. These inserts gave localized accounts of where to find good hunting and fishing, as well as outlined environmental threats to local rivers, lakes, and forests.

Though East was a long-standing and well regarded editor, his true gift was as a writer. East wrote and ghostwrote hundreds of stories for Outdoor Life until, and even after, his retirement in 1972. He earned the nickname the 'dean of outdoor writers' in recognition of his long career and his commitment to mentoring the aspiring writers who worked under and with him. He not only gained the respect of other writers, but the entire sporting community. He worked closely with hunters and sportsmen across the country to capture their stories and publish them under their own names. Many of the stories in this collection are attributed to other writers, but were in fact authored by East. In addition to his magazine and newspaper writing, East authored a number of books, notably of adventure stories, though he also published a novel and The Ben East Hunting Book--a comprehensive how-to book.

Though Ben East is most remembered as a writer he was also an early and important conservationist. He was deeply committed to preserving Michigan's natural beauty and was instrumental in gaining State Park status for both Tahquamenon Falls and the Porcupine Mountains. He also played a major role in securing Isle Royale as a National Park. He was involved in a number of conservation organizations and won the Michigan United Conservation Clubs Conservation Award in 1971 as well the Michigan Environmental Award and formal recognition by the Michigan state legislature, both in 1973.

scopecontent.p: The Ben East papers contain material dating from as early as 1935 and spanning the next 45 years of his career as an outdoorsman, writer, and conservationist with the bulk of the materials focusing on his career as an outdoor writer and editor. The collection is divided into five series: Editorial Copy, Personal Papers, Photographs, Publications, and Topical Files.

The Editorial Copy series contains pre-print version of columns, articles, and stories for a number of different publications. The series is divided into subseries according to which publication the article originally appeared in, including the Detroit News, the Michigan Outdoor Almanac, and columns written for Outdoor Life. The largest subseries contains the editorial copy for the Outdoor Life regional inserts Mr. East edited throughout his career at the magazine. This subseries spans 19 years, from 1961-1978, though there are many chronological gaps in this subseries. The Editorial Copy series focuses on Mr. East's regular editorial duties such as recurring columns and assignments; feature articles for Outdoor Life are located in the Topical Files series and arranged by the subject matter of the article.
The Personal Papers section contains Ben East's personal correspondence, as well as files about awards and recognition that he received for his work.

The Photographs series contains files of photographic material in several forms including prints, negatives, slides, and clippings of 16mm filmstrips. Many of these photographs were included in Outdoor Life and are of professional quality. This series contains files that were exclusively photographic; photographic material that was integrated into files also containing print material in Mr. East's topical files remain in those files and that material is distributed throughout the collection.

Ben East's full-length books are included in the Publications series of the collection. This series included these books, as well as files pertaining to their publishing or copyright. The collection does not contain a full catalog of East's books, but has a representative sample, including The Ben East Hunting Book and several editions in multiple languages of the Reader's Digest containing a condensed version of his book Silence of the North.

did.unittitle: Silence of the North movie rights
Outdoor Life Book of Narrow Escapes
Reader's Digest Silence of the North

scopecontent.p: The largest and most extensive series in the collection is Ben East's Topical Files. Mr. East kept reference files on many types of plants and animals he encountered in his work as an outdoor writer, and included in these reference files any stories he had written on a particular topic. These Topical Files are divided into seven subseries: Adventure Stories, Birds, Conservation, Fish and Fishing, Mammals and Game Animals, Michigan Places, and Miscellaneous. These files contain numerous clippings as well as some of Ben East's best writing, both under his name and stories that he ghostwrote which appear under the names of his associates. The Michigan Places subseries includes a great deal of correspondence and other material relating to his efforts to dedicate Michigan's wilderness as state and national parks.
